arch:property.oc:show_val: This locus is the subfloor fill below the surface L169. L169 was likely one of a series of surfaces pushed together with little or no fill between, and there are still pieces of these surfaces present on the exposed layer of this fill. Either there is a poorly preserved surface in this fill or the surface above was irregular and not level. On the northwestern corner of the fill is a particularly large section of surface belonging to the layers above this locus, measuring to about 3ft. In excavating the locus we left this in place until the rest had gone down about 5cm to make sure it was nothing different, and then took it out as apart of the locus. There is not a lot of artifacts, rocks, or anything of the sort in this fill. It had few inclusions and produced small amounts of pottery, lithic, shell, and bone. Its border with the ashy soil of L167 is fairly undefined, and the ashy runs into this locus quite a bit.
almost no inclusions of very small rocks.

arch:note.arch:string: Contexts excavated in trenches were recorded using the "locus system." A locus is any discrete three-dimensional entity excavated in a trench. The key to the locus system is the recognition that a locus is any one thing. Differences in soil composition or texture are therefore as important as, for example, the difference between a pit and a wall. If two entities were distinct, they were considered separate loci and were therefore assigned separate locus numbers. It should also be noted that every context excavated in a trench was given a locus number and thus the trench itself is made up completely of excavated loci.

oc:metadata.dc:title: Kenan Tepe: Area E / Trench 2 / Locus 170 (Locus)
